intro: Chaerophyllum procumbens var. dasycarpum, commonly known as the hairy-fruited hogweed, is a low-growing perennial plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It features a rosette of basal leaves that are deeply lobed and covered in fine hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in umbrella-like inflorescences, typical of the Apiaceae family. Its leaves and stems contain various bioactive compounds, which have been studied for potential medicinal uses. However, it is important to note that some members of this genus can be toxic, requiring caution in handling or consumption.
